results.title: How the Taliban Turned Social Media Into a Tool for Control
results.abstract: In the 1990s, they banned the internet. Now they use it to threaten and cajole the Afghan people, in a sign of how they might use technology to build power.
results.byline: By Paul Mozur and Zia ur-Rehman

results.title: ‘Super Taster’ Who Lost Sense of Smell Is Helping Italians Regain It
results.abstract: A celebrated epicure in Italy was devastated when Covid-19 first stole, then warped his sense of taste. Through training, Michele Crippa has recaptured some of it and is now on a quest to aid others.

multimedia.caption: Michele Crippa, center, a celebrated gourmand in Italy, experienced a devastating loss because of Covid-19: his sense of smell.

results.title: As Chinese Vaccines Stumble, U.S. Finds New Opening in Asia
results.abstract: Several Southeast Asian nations are raising doubts about the efficacy of China’s vaccines. The Biden administration has recently offered to provide shots, “no strings attached.”
results.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Steven Lee Myers

results.title: South Koreans Now Dislike China More Than They Dislike Japan
results.abstract: There is growing anti-China sentiment in South Korea, particularly among young voters. Conservative politicians are eager to turn the antipathy into a presidential election issue.

multimedia.caption: People in the streets of Seoul this month. Anti-Chinese sentiment has grown so much this year that China has replaced Japan as the most disliked nation by South Koreans.

des_facet: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

results.title: Nicole Kidman’s Quarantine Pass Generates Anger in Hong Kong
results.abstract: The actress, in Hong Kong to film a series about wealthy expatriates, was allowed to skip a coronavirus quarantine. Residents saw the exemption as deeply unfair, and it became a point of debate among lawmakers.

results.title: 1946: Vatican Newspaper Denounces a Pistol Duel
results.abstract: The Osservatore Romano complained that the shootout between two Romans — despite leaving neither hurt — hinted at the societal ills that had flourished in postwar Italy.

results.title: A 17-year-old Afghan soccer player died falling from a U.S. evacuation plane.
results.abstract: Frantic to flee the Taliban, Zaki Anwari joined a desperate crush at the Kabul airport. “He had no hope and wanted a better life,” a sports official said.

multimedia.caption: Zaki Anwari died at the Kabul airport while trying to flee Kabul, his soccer federation said.
